<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 356, 233]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 327, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 573]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 573, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 620]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 557, 94]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) in the expansion of \(\left(2 - \frac{1}{2} x\right)^{7}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 74, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 128, 97, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 123, 732, 156]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \frac{1}{x^3} - x^3\), for \(x > 0\). Show that f is a decreasing function.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 128, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 183, 97, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 583, 202]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(7\cos x + 5 = 2\sin^{2}x\), for \(0^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 202]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 230, 97, 248]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 240, 698, 406]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(D\) lies on the side \(AB\) of triangle \(ABC\) and \(CD\) is an arc of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(2\mathrm{~cm}\). The line \(BC\) is of length \(2\sqrt{3}\mathrm{~cm}\) and is perpendicular to \(AC\). Find the area of the shaded region \(BDC\), giving your answer in terms of \(\pi\) and \(\sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 456, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 502, 96, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 501, 740, 522]]<|/det|>
The first term of a geometric progression is \(5\frac{1}{3}\) and the fourth term is \(2\frac{1}{4}\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 528, 156, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 528, 306, 546]]<|/det|>
the common ratio,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 552, 311, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label> the sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 598, 96, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 597, 547, 618]]<|/det|>
The functions f and g are defined for \(- \frac{1}{2}\pi \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 625, 561, 647]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {f}(x) = \frac{1}{2} x + \frac{1}{6}\pi ,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 650, 544, 668]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {g}(x) = \cos x.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 677, 504, 698]]<|/det|>
Solve the following equations for \(- \frac{1}{2}\pi \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 710, 153, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 710, 510, 728]]<|/det|>
gf(\(x\)) = 1, giving your answer in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 740, 153, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 740, 626, 758]]<|/det|>
fg(\(x\)) = 1, giving your answers correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 740, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 81, 688, 365]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 380, 158, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 380, 920, 418]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = 11 - x^2\) and part of the straight line \(y = 5 - x\) meeting at the point \(A\) \((p, q)\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are positive constants. Find the values of \(p\) and \(q\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 425, 153, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 551, 444]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined for the domain \(x \geqslant 0\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 446, 636, 485]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}11 - x^{2} & \mathrm{for} 0\leqslant x\leqslant p,\\ 5 - x & \mathrm{for} x > p. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 411, 509]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) in a similar way.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 491, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 532, 96, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 281, 551]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 549, 603, 579]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{d}\mathrm{x}} = 2(3\mathrm{x} + 4)^{\frac{3}{2}} - 6\mathrm{x} - 8.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 597, 148, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 596, 240, 626]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 602, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 635, 153, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 635, 804, 654]]<|/det|>
Verify that the curve has a stationary point when \(x = -1\) and determine its nature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 664, 153, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 664, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
It is now given that the stationary point on the curve has coordinates \((-1, 5)\). Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 720, 96, 739]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 720, 710, 739]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of points \(A\) and \(B\) relative to an origin \(O\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 742, 636, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\overrightarrow{OA} = \left( \begin{array}{c}p\\ 1 \end{array} \right)\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \overrightarrow{OB} = \left( \begin{array}{c}4\\ 2 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 793, 292, 812]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 820, 153, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 820, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(OAB\) is a straight line, state the value of \(p\) and find the unit vector in the direction of \(\overrightarrow{OA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 851, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 867, 153, 885]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 867, 752, 885]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(OA\) is perpendicular to \(AB\), find the possible values of \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 868, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 894, 153, 912]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 894, 920, 927]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(p = 3\), the point \(C\) is such that \(OABC\) is a parallelogram. Find the position vector of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 912, 920, 929]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 104, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 905, 104]]<|/det|>
A straight line has equation \(y = - 2x + k\), where \(k\) is a constant, and a curve has equation \(y = \frac{2}{x - 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 112, 154, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 112, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinates of any points of intersection of the line and curve are given by the equation \(2x^{2} - (6 + k)x + (2 + 3k) = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 148]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 160, 153, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 159, 698, 179]]<|/det|>
Find the two values of \(k\) for which the line is a tangent to the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 161, 920, 179]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 190, 873, 210]]<|/det|>
The two tangents, given by the values of \(k\) found in part (ii), touch the curve at points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 148, 240]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 222, 670, 241]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(A\) and \(B\) and the equation of the line \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 222, 920, 241]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 102, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 276, 757, 457]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 480, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = x(x - 2)^2\). The minimum point on the curve has coordinates \((a, 0)\) and the \(x\)-coordinate of the maximum point is \(b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 528, 156, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 528, 320, 546]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 559, 153, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 559, 316, 576]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 576]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 148, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 588, 437, 606]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 588, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 625, 153, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 621, 767, 648]]<|/det|>
The gradient, \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\), of the curve has a minimum value \(m\). Find the value of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 626, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
